data.title: Waybill vs. Bill of Lading: What’s the difference?
data.meta_description: Understand the differences between a Bill of Lading and a Waybill. Learn what they are, who issues them, and their role in your shipping operations.
data.text:
Freight transport, or shipping, is a cornerstone of global commerce. It involves various transportation modes, regulations, practices, and paperwork, all working together to make things run smoothly and efficiently.

When shipping goods by air, land, or sea, you’ll typically need either a waybill or a bill of lading, along with other necessary documents. To make sure your shipping process goes off without a hitch, it’s important to understand the differences between these two documents. So let’s dive in and take a closer look at what each one is all about!

What is a Bill of Lading?

A bill of lading can be described as a legally binding document between the entity that ships goods and the carrier that specifies the type, quantity, and destination of the goods. It serves as:

A receipt of goods

A contract

A document of title

The bill of lading is used to ensure the proper and timely delivery of goods to their destination.

Who Issues a Bill of Lading?

If you were wondering where to obtain a bill of lading, it’s generally provided by the carrier or the carrier’s agent. In some cases, a third party may also be involved in the process.

Releasing the Original Bill of Lading at the Destination Port

The original bill of lading needs to be presented to the carrier at the destination port before the cargo can be released by the consignee (or the consignee’s agent). The document is usually handed over in exchange for the goods, at which point it serves as a receipt. It can also be sent electronically in case of a telex or an express release.

What Information Can be Found in a Bill of Lading?

The information on a bill of lading includes:

Shipper’s Information: The name and address of the person or company shipping the goods.

Consignee’s Information: The name and address of the person or company to whom the goods are being shipped.

Purchase Orders or Special Reference Numbers: These numbers are used by the shipper or consignee to track specific shipments. When handling multiple shipments or when a shipment is part of a larger transaction, this becomes especially crucial.

Special Instructions: These may include special handling directions, information about dangerous goods, or other important details that the carrier needs to know to handle the shipment properly.

Date of Shipment: The date on which the goods are handed over to the carrier for transport.

Number of Shipping Units: This could be the number of boxes, pallets, or other units being shipped.

Type of Packaging: This can include anything from boxes and pallets to drums, crates, or other packaging.

Description of Goods: A detailed description of the items being shipped, including their contents, material composition, and potentially their Harmonized System (HS) codes for customs purposes.

Volume, Weight, and Freight Dimensions: The shipment’s dimensions, weight, and sometimes volume.

Declared Value of Goods: The value of the goods as declared by the shipper. This information is important for insurance purposes and customs if the shipment crosses international borders.

What Types of Bill of Lading Forms Are There?

Shippers should be familiar with several types of bills of lading. Furthermore, it’s important to understand which type of bill of lading is required based on how the shipped goods will be handled. Of course, these aren’t all the types, but the most commonly used.

Original Bill of Lading: This is the first and most important form of the bill of lading. It gives title and control of the goods, and customers typically need the original form as proof of ownership to take possession of the items.

Straight Bill of Lading: A non-negotiable bill of lading. It is used when the goods have been paid for or do not require payment (gifts or donations).

Order Bill of Lading: A negotiable bill of lading. It can be bought, sold, or traded while the goods are in transit. Customers commonly need an original form as proof of ownership to take possession of the goods.

Bearer Bill of Lading: This type of bill of lading does not specify a singular recipient. Instead, it is issued to the “bearer” or “holder” of the document, making it highly negotiable. Furthermore, it poses a risk since anyone in possession of the original document has the right to claim the goods.

Switch Bill of Lading: A second set of bills of lading issued by the carrier or the carrier’s agent. It is given in exchange for the original bills of lading for the purpose of transferring the title of good from one party to the other.

Master Bill of Lading: Issued by the main carrier of goods, this document covers the entire transportation process, including all legs of the journey.

Each type of bill of lading has its own particular uses, advantages, and risks. The type of bill of lading selected for a shipment depends on the shipment details and the requirements of the shipper and receiver. It must also comply with the laws and regulations of both the origin and destination countries. Choosing the right type of bill of lading is critical to ensure smooth and timely delivery of goods, as well as legal protection.

What is a Waybill?

A waybill is a document issued by a carrier detailing the contents of the shipment, the route, the sender and the receiver:

It’s a receipt for the sender, evidence of the contract of carriage, and a guide of the shipment transport to its final destination.

Waybills can typically be obtained from the carrier or shipping company.

When a business or individual decides to ship goods, they contact a carrier who provides them with a waybill. They might also hire an expert to assist them with this process.

The carrier uses this document as a guide for transporting the goods and gives it to the recipient as proof of delivery.

What Information Can Be Found in a Waybill?

While specific details may vary depending on the type of waybill, it typically includes the following elements:

Shipper’s Name and Address: Information of the party sending the goods.

Consignee’s Name and Address: Information of the party receiving the goods.

Billing Information: Information of the party responsible for the payment of the shipping charges.

Carrier’s Information: The name and address of the transportation company moving the goods.

Description of Goods: Detailed information about the goods being transported: type, quantity, weight, and other special handling instructions.

Packaging Type: Information on the goods’ packaging (for example, in boxes, crates, pallets, etc.).

Number of Packages: The total number of packages or units in the shipment.

Gross Weight: The total weight of the shipment including packaging and pallets.

Dimensions: The size of the shipment or individual packages: length, width, and height.

Date of Shipment: The date when the goods were handed over to the carrier.

Place of Receipt: The location where the goods were received by the carrier.

Place of Delivery: The destination to which the carrier delivers the goods.

Freight and Other Charges: Details of the shipping cost, including any additional charges for special handling or services.

Declared Value for Customs: The value of the goods as declared by the shipper for customs purposes.

Instructions for Carrier: Any specific instructions from the shipper to the carrier.

Shipment Route: The planned route of the shipment, including any transshipment points.

Terms and Conditions: Standard terms and conditions of carriage that are part of the contract between the shipper and the carrier.

Signatures: The signatures of the shipper and the carrier or their representatives as confirmation of the contract of carriage.

The specific layout and format of a waybill may vary depending on the carrier and the mode of transport. However, these are the common elements you would typically find on a waybill. The waybill serves as a crucial document for the shipper, the carrier, and the consignee.

What Types of Waybill Forms Are There?

There are various types of waybills shippers should be familiar with:

Air Waybill (AWB): Used for air freight, this waybill serves as proof of receipt of the goods for shipment. It provides details about the goods and the agreed-upon conditions of transport and is proof of the contract of carriage.

Railway Waybill: Similar to a bill of lading, this waybill is specific to rail transport.

Truck Waybill: A document provided by a carrier to a shipper for road freight. This waybill is signed by the carrier entity or the driver who has carried the shipment.

Sea Waybill: A transport contract (document of carriage) used in international trade. It serves as a receipt of goods by a carrier (such as a shipping line) for transportation from the consignor (the shipper) to the consignee.

Sea Waybill vs. Bill of Lading

A bill of lading is a legal document issued by a carrier to a shipper that details the type, quantity, and destination of the goods. It serves as a shipment receipt when the goods are delivered, a contract between the shipper and the carrier, and a document of title proving ownership of the goods.

A sea waybill, on the other hand, is a non-negotiable transport document. It provides evidence of a contract for carriage and receipt of the goods, but unlike a bill of lading, it does not convey ownership. That is, the goods can be delivered to the named consignee without presenting the original document. As such, sea waybills are often used for trusted relationships or when goods are paid for in advance as they allow for faster and more efficient deliveries.

Air Waybill vs. Bill of Lading

An air waybill is a contract between the shipper and the airline outlining the terms and conditions of air transportation. It acts as a receipt for the goods and evidence of the carriage contract, but it’s not a title document, making it non-negotiable.

In contrast, a bill of lading is issued by a carrier or their agent to acknowledge receipt of cargo for shipment. Unlike AWBs, BOLs are typically negotiable documents and represent ownership of the goods. In other words, they can be bought, sold, or traded while in transit.

Can I Use Both?

Typically, you wouldn’t use both documents together because they serve overlapping purposes but are used differently. You would use either a bill of lading or a waybill, depending on specific requirements such as the mode of transport, whether it’s air or sea, and the nature of the transaction.

In sea freight, a bill of lading is typically the preferred option. This is due to its negotiability and its role as a title document, which is crucial when ownership needs to be transferred during long transit times. In contrast, the air waybill is non-negotiable, which streamlines the process but offers no flexibility for ownership changes during transit. This non-negotiability aligns with the shorter transit times and simpler routing of air transport, which reduces the necessity for ownership transfers while goods are in transit.

Bill of Lading vs. Waybill: Importing Into Canada and the U.S.

In addition to other shipping documents, most countries ask for a bill of lading or a waybill for customs clearance. The United States follows the same procedure and requires that you present an ocean bill of lading, an inland bill of lading, or an air waybill for air cargo. Similarly, a bill of lading or waybill is needed when shipping from or to Canada.
